| A gnoll ghoul:* can [survive underwater](/wiki/Amphibious "Amphibious").
* [does not breathe](/wiki/Breathless "Breathless").
* is [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless").
* has [a head, a couple of arms, and a torso](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid").
* is [poisonous](/wiki/Poisonous "Poisonous") to eat.
* [does not eat](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate"). (\*)
* is [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead").
* is normally generated [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile").
* wanders randomly.
* has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision").
* appears only in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom").
* [never leaves a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless").
* resists death magic.
* does not naturally [regenerate](/wiki/Regenerate "Regenerate") HP. |                                                                                           |

A **gnoll ghoul**, Z, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"). It is a [zombified](/wiki/Zombie_\(dNetHack\) "Zombie (dNetHack)") form of [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") [gnoll](/wiki/Gnoll#dNetHack "Gnoll") that has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") and is [unbreathing](/wiki/Unbreathing "Unbreathing") and [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless") like many other undead monsters.

A gnoll ghoul has a weapon attack, a claw attack, and a bite that can [paralyze](/wiki/Paralyze "Paralyze") targets similar to the claw attacks of standard [ghouls](/wiki/Ghoul "Ghoul"). They possess [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance"), [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance"), [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance"), and [resistance to death magic](/wiki/Death_resistance "Death resistance").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 Origin](#Origin)
- [4 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

Gnoll ghouls are only randomly generated in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"), and are always created hostile.

Eleven gnoll ghouls are randomly placed around [the lair of Yeenoghu](/wiki/User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Lord_Levels#Yeenoghu.2C_Demon_Lord_of_Gnolls_and_Ghouls "User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Lord Levels") at level creation, and they also make up 1⁄10 of the monsters randomly generated there.

A gnoll ghoul [does not leave a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless") upon death.

Player characters that are killed by gnoll ghouls and leave a [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") file will arise as a named ghoul instead of a [ghost](/wiki/Ghost "Ghost").

## Strategy

Gnoll ghouls lack the [HP](/wiki/HP "HP") and melee damage their living kin possess, but compensate for it somewhat with their paralyzing bite. Since dNetHack uses [3.4.3's magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation_\(3.4.3\) "Magic cancellation (3.4.3)"), MC3 makes the paralysis negligible, and [free action](/wiki/Free_action "Free action") blocks it completely.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Gnole](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gnole "wikipedia:Gnole")***

The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection *[The Book of Wonder](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Book_of_Wonder "wikipedia:The Book of Wonder")* by [Lord Dunsany](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Dunsany "wikipedia:Lord Dunsany"), with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* is introduced in [the first boxed set](https://archive.org/details/monsters_and_treasures/page/7/mode/2up) of the game, and gnolls are described in *Book 2: Monsters and Treasure* as a "cross between [Gnomes](/wiki/Gnome "Gnome") and [Trolls](/wiki/Troll "Troll") (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power. The 1st Monster Manual for *Advanced Dungeons & Dragons* and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces [Yeenoghu](/wiki/Yeenoghu "Yeenoghu"), the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship.

Yeenoghu is also the demon god of ghouls, as established in the 3.5e *Fiendish Codex I* and retold in material of later editions: he gained dominion over them by subjugating of Doresain, the King of the Ghouls. Doresain was a former vassal of [Orcus](/wiki/Orcus "Orcus") and controlled his own layer of the Abyss, the White Kingdom, until Yeenoghu’s army invaded and conquered them; the King of Ghouls swore fealty to Yeenoghu and had paid him homage since as a sworn ally, and the Prince of Gnolls rules all ghouls through his new vassal. As of yet, Orcus has not retaliated against Yeenoghu for this, with his attention being elsewhere.

## Encyclopedia entry

We are born and we die.  
No one cares, no one remembers,  
and it doesn't matter.  
This is why we laugh.  
\[ The Gnoll Credo, by J. Stanton ]

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

Gnoll ghoul

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Z gnoll ghoul
Difficulty 15
Attacks Weapon 1d8 physical, Claw 1d4 physical, Bite 2d2 paralysis
Z gnoll ghoul
Difficulty 15
Attacks

Weapon 1d8 physical, Claw 1d4 physical, Bite 2d2 paralysis

Base level 12
Base experience 327
Speed 12
Base AC 0
Base MR 0
Alignment -2 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 1600
Nutritional value 400
Size medium
Resistances cold, sleep, poison
Resistances conveyed none

A gnoll ghoul:

  • can survive underwater.
  • does not breathe.
  • is mindless.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is poisonous to eat.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is undead.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • wanders randomly.
  • has infravision.
  • appears only in Gehennom.
  • never leaves a corpse.
  • resists death magic.
  • does not naturally regenerate HP.

A gnoll ghoul, Z, is a type of monster that appears in dNetHack and notdNetHack. It is a zombified form of undead gnoll that has infravision and is unbreathing and mindless like many other undead monsters.

A gnoll ghoul has a weapon attack, a claw attack, and a bite that can paralyze targets similar to the claw attacks of standard ghouls. They possess cold resistance, sleep resistance, poison resistance, and resistance to death magic.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 Origin
  • 4 Encyclopedia entry

Generation

Gnoll ghouls are only randomly generated in Gehennom, and are always created hostile.

Eleven gnoll ghouls are randomly placed around the lair of Yeenoghu at level creation, and they also make up 1⁄10 of the monsters randomly generated there.

A gnoll ghoul does not leave a corpse upon death.

Player characters that are killed by gnoll ghouls and leave a bones file will arise as a named ghoul instead of a ghost.

Strategy

Gnoll ghouls lack the HP and melee damage their living kin possess, but compensate for it somewhat with their paralyzing bite. Since dNetHack uses 3.4.3's magic cancellation, MC3 makes the paralysis negligible, and free action blocks it completely.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Gnole

The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection The Book of Wonder by Lord Dunsany, with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of Dungeons & Dragons is introduced in the first boxed set of the game, and gnolls are described in Book 2: Monsters and Treasure as a "cross between Gnomes and Trolls (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power. The 1st Monster Manual for Advanced Dungeons & Dragons and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces Yeenoghu, the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship.

Yeenoghu is also the demon god of ghouls, as established in the 3.5e Fiendish Codex I and retold in material of later editions: he gained dominion over them by subjugating of Doresain, the King of the Ghouls. Doresain was a former vassal of Orcus and controlled his own layer of the Abyss, the White Kingdom, until Yeenoghu’s army invaded and conquered them; the King of Ghouls swore fealty to Yeenoghu and had paid him homage since as a sworn ally, and the Prince of Gnolls rules all ghouls through his new vassal. As of yet, Orcus has not retaliated against Yeenoghu for this, with his attention being elsewhere.

Encyclopedia entry

We are born and we die.
No one cares, no one remembers,
and it doesn't matter.
This is why we laugh.
[ The Gnoll Credo, by J. Stanton ]

A '''gnoll ghoul''', {{black|Z}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in [[dNetHack]] and [[notdNetHack]]. It is a [[Zombie (dNetHack)|zombified]] form of [[undead]] [[Gnoll#dNetHack|gnoll]] that has [[infravision]] and is [[unbreathing]] and [[mindless]] like many other undead monsters.

A gnoll ghoul has a weapon attack, a claw attack, and a bite that can [[paralyze]] targets similar to the claw attacks of standard [[ghoul]]s. They possess [[cold resistance]], [[sleep resistance]], [[poison resistance]], and [[Death resistance|resistance to death magic]].

==Generation==
Gnoll ghouls are only randomly generated in [[Gehennom]], and are always created hostile.

Eleven gnoll ghouls are randomly placed around [[User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Lord Levels#Yeenoghu, Demon Lord of Gnolls and Ghouls|the lair of Yeenoghu]] at level creation, and they also make up {{frac|10}} of the monsters randomly generated there. 

A gnoll ghoul [[Corpseless|does not leave a corpse]] upon death.

Player characters that are killed by gnoll ghouls and leave a [[bones]] file will arise as a named ghoul instead of a [[ghost]].

==Strategy==
Gnoll ghouls lack the [[HP]] and melee damage their living kin possess, but compensate for it somewhat with their paralyzing bite. Since dNetHack uses [[Magic cancellation (3.4.3)|3.4.3's magic cancellation]], MC3 makes the paralysis negligible, and [[free action]] blocks it completely.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Gnole}}
The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection ''[[wikipedia:The Book of Wonder|The Book of Wonder]]'' by [[wikipedia:Lord Dunsany|Lord Dunsany]], with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' is introduced in [https://archive.org/details/monsters_and_treasures/page/7/mode/2up the first boxed set] of the game, and gnolls are described in ''Book 2: Monsters and Treasure'' as a "cross between [[Gnome]]s and [[Troll]]s (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power. The 1st Monster Manual for ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces [[Yeenoghu]], the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship.

Yeenoghu is also the demon god of ghouls, as established in the 3.5e ''Fiendish Codex I'' and retold in material of later editions: he gained dominion over them by subjugating of Doresain, the King of the Ghouls. Doresain was a former vassal of [[Orcus]] and controlled his own layer of the Abyss, the White Kingdom, until Yeenoghu’s army invaded and conquered them; the King of Ghouls swore fealty to Yeenoghu and had paid him homage since as a sworn ally, and the Prince of Gnolls rules all ghouls through his new vassal. As of yet, Orcus has not retaliated against Yeenoghu for this, with his attention being elsewhere.
